p.s: In his speech Barnier states, that Brexit is clearly a lose-lose situation for both the EU and the UK, which is a controverse statement.
The first part, that Brexit is a lose for the UK is undisputably true, so there is only need to argue, if the UK leaving is a lose for the EU.
LoosingLosing a member means a reduced tax income for the EU, and also a lost trade partner, but it also means that there is less income to spend on the UK, meaning it still has some positives.
But the positives are vastly smaller than the downsides, which also include the economic disturbance and less freedoms, like free travel across Europe as a whole.
So I think, that while some may disagree, all in all Brexit was a lose-lose situation, even if the UK suffered a lot more than the EU.
